item.title: Army Kills 51, Deepening Crisis in Egypt
item.description: In a sharp escalation of tensions Monday, Egyptian soldiers opened fire on hundreds of supporters of Mohamed Morsi, the ousted president, witnesses said. The military said armed assailants fired first.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:credit: Narciso Contreras for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man grieved for a relative who was among those killed in Egypt.

item.title: Europe Keeps Pressure on Athens
item.description: After a week of tense negotiations, Greece and its foreign lenders agreed on a new round of austerity measures that must be taken by the country to unlock the crucial rescue funds.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN, NIKI KITSANTONIS and JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Yannis Stournaras, the finance minister of Greece, met with Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, in Brussels on Monday.

item.title: Pollution Leads to Drop in Life Span in Northern China, Study Finds
item.description: Widespread coal use in the north has led in recent decades to an average decrease in life span of more than five years, research indicates.
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Pollution from widespread coal use in northern China has led to an average decrease in life span, research shows.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: July 8
item.description: Jaguar Land Rover Limited launched its new F-Type two-seater car on Monday in Mumbai, Maharashtra.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Matthew Beaven, right, chief designer of exteriors advanced design at Jaguar, with the new Jaguar F-Type car during its launch in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

item.title: India Ink: A Grocer to Delhi’s Poor
item.description: Arjun Abrol’s “fair price” shop is one of about 2500 stores in Delhi that sell subsidized grain to the poor under government’s public distribution program.
item.dc:creator: By PAMPOSH RAINA
item.media:description: Arjun Abrol, a fair price shop owner, dealing with his customers in Paharganj, New Delhi.

item.title: Another Leader Quits Post in Syrian Exile Group
item.description: It was not immediately clear why the group’s prime minister, Ghassan Hitto, resigned two days after it elected a new president.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By HANIA MOURTADA and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Free Syrian Army fighters during an offensive against forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad, in Aleppo, on Monday.

item.title: The Lede: Video of San Francisco Air Crash Emerges
item.description: Footage, shot by an amateur cameraman, corroborates eyewitness accounts of the plane’s descent and crash.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA

item.title: Czech Prosecutors Prepare to Charge Ex-Premier
item.description: The Czech Parliament was asked to strip former Prime Minister Petr Necas of immunity from prosecution, a prelude to corruption charges being filed against him.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Petr Necas of the Czech Republic, once "Mr. Clean Hands," became mired in scandal and quit.

item.title: New Prayer Confrontation at Western Wall
item.description: Two ultra-Orthodox men were arrested on suspicion of throwing objects at the women in an activist group, in the latest clash at one of Judaism’s holiest sites.
item.dc:creator: By ALYZA SEBENIUS and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: A member of the Women of the Wall organization, which recently won a court decision protecting women’s right to wear religious garments traditionally used by men, prayed while wearing a prayer shawl outside the Western Wall on Monday.

item.title: Lo Hsing Han, Wealthy Trafficker From Myanmar, Dies at 80
item.description: Mr. Lo was an opium and heroin trafficker who became one of Myanmar’s richest men and a potent symbol of the ability of the country’s drug warlords to operate with impunity.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Lo Hsing Han, who President Richard M. Nixon called the “kingpin of the heroin traffic in Southeast Asia,” in 2007.

item.title: India Ink: Kashmiri Artist Builds Bridges with Facebook Exhibit
item.description: More than 200 images of Masood Hussain’s watercolors on Srinagar have set off long conversations about shared and separate memories of Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: By CHITRA PADMANABHAN

item.title: Letter from Europe: Human Rights and European Union Foreign Policy
item.description: The E.U. and European governments face a dilemma: How can human rights -- supposedly at the center of Europe's foreign policy -- best be promoted?
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By JUDY DEMPSEY

item.title: Ex-Rail Minister in China Gets a Suspended Death Sentence
item.description: Liu Zhijun, 60, a former minister of railways, confessed to taking millions in bribes in return for providing access to China’s huge spending on its train network expansion.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER BUCKLEY

item.title: Asiana President Says Pilot Was in Training
item.description: Asiana Flight 214, which crashed at San Francisco International Airport on Saturday, was “a training flight” for the pilot, the airline’s president said Monday.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Islamist Party Backs Out of Negotiations
item.description: Al Nour, seen as a potential political kingmaker, said it was suspending its role in efforts to form an interim government.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: China Ex-Rail Boss Gets Suspended Death for Graft
item.description: China's former railways minister Liu Zhijun was given a suspended death sentence Monday that will likely be commuted to life imprisonment for bribery and abuse of power in one of the country's highest-profile corruption cases in years.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Singapore Inquest Rules American Killed Himself
item.description: A judge ruled Monday that an American engineer who was found dead in his apartment in Singapore last year killed himself, rejecting suspicions by the man's parents that he was murdered because of research into sensitive technology.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Islamist Party a Surprise Force in a New Egypt
item.description: Al Nour, a party of ultraconservative Islamists, has emerged as an unexpected political kingmaker, shaping the interim government after the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Brazil Voices ‘Deep Concern’ Over Gathering of Data by U.S.
item.description: Brazil’s foreign minister said his government would press the United Nations to take action that “preserves the sovereignty of all countries.”
item.dc:creator: By LARRY ROHTER

item.title: For Chinese Families, a Journey Cut Short, and With It Their Dreams
item.description: The two 16-year-old victims of Asiana Flight 214 were among 34 10th-grade Chinese students and chaperones who were bound for a summer camp outside Los Angeles.
item.dc:creator: By VIVIAN YEE
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The two Chinese teenagers who died in Asiana Flight 214, Ye Mengyuan and Wang Linjia, were scheduled to attend summer camp at West Valley Christian School outside Los Angeles.

item.title: Deadly Derailment in Quebec Underlines Oil Debate
item.description: The accident, in which at least five people were killed, underscored a debate about whether it is safer to transport oil by rail or pipeline.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: People attended a Mass in Sainte-Cécile-de-Whitton, Quebec, to pray for victims of a train derailment in Lac-Mégantic.

item.title: Terror on Jet: Seeing Water, Not Runway
item.description: The pilot at the controls on Asiana Flight 214 was said to have had only 43 hours of experience flying a Boeing 777, and an airline spokeswoman said that it was his first time piloting a 777 into San Francisco.
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI, CHRISTOPHER DREW, MATTHEW L. WALD and SARAH MASLIN NIR
item.media:description: Investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board on Sunday at the scene of the crash of Asiana Airlines Flight 214 at San Francisco International Airport.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Perils of a ‘People’s Coup’
item.description: Egyptians celebrating today could be behind bars tomorrow.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By KHALED M. ABOU EL FADL

item.title: Brotherhood Says U.S. Diplomats Urged It to Accept Ouster of Morsi
item.description: American diplomats contacted Muslim Brotherhood leaders to try to persuade them to re-enter the political process, an Islamist briefed on one of the conversations said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Narciso Contreras for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of ousted President Mohamed Morsi gathered outside the officers’ club of the Republican Guard on Sunday.

item.title: Doha Journal: Too Hot to Exercise (and Who Really Wants To?)
item.description: Qataris, who have a high obesity rate, are being urged to try to keep fit by walking in malls, where they can escape temperatures that are often over 100 degrees.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mall in Doha, Qatar. Qataris, who have a high obesity rate, are being urged to try to keep fit by walking in malls, where they can escape temperatures that are often over 100 degrees.
